abstract.text: An attribute that represents grammatical agreement for objects that aren’t part of the inflected text.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use this formatting attribute for cases where you need to inflect text based on a term of address or phrase that’s not part of the inflected text.

content.text: Agree with a term of address

inlineContent.text: In languages that rely on gender, the words and phrases in a sentence need to grammatically agree. For example, suppose you need to translate the following sentence into Spanish:
The challenge is that the system doesn’t know the preferred term of address for the person named
. Additionally, most often, the localization file only contains masculine forms of translated words. This means the system can’t correctly inflect other words in the sentence, such as
, to agree with Anne’s feminine name. So the resulting translation is:
is masculine, which isn’t the correct gender agreement for the sentence.
attribute can help. By wrapping the word you want to seek agreement on,
attribute pointing to an inflection concept of type
, the system makes the masculine word
. You don’t need to include masculine and feminine forms of the translated words in your localization files. The system makes the terms agree for you.
The following steps ensure proper gender agreement in the translation:
Create a type associating the name
term of address. For example, create a
structure containing two properties — one property representing Anne’s name and another (an array) representing Anne’s preferred terms of address.
containing the English key phrase from the Spanish localization file to translate, along with the name
as a placeholder variable representing the word to agree with.
and pass an inflection concept of type
containing the term of address associated with the name
In the Spanish localization file, wrap the Spanish term,
attribute, with the index pointing to the first inflection concept instance in the
by passing the resource and options to a new

code: // Define the resource you want to apply grammatical agreement to.
// Set the inflection concept to use a term of address.
// Make a new string imposing grammatical agreement on the resource from the term of address.
let result = AttributedString(localized: resource, options: options)

inlineContent.text: Using a localized phrase for grammatical agreement is the same as using a term of address except you inflect on an
instead of a term of address.
For example, suppose you need to translate the following sentence for a food order into Spanish:
Last time you ordered the small.
can appear on its own. But in Spanish, that translated word needs to agree with the masculine or feminine noun it’s describing, which, in this case (
To achieve agreement, wrap the masculine word for
attribute. Then set it to point to the
that matches its associated food item.
The following steps ensure proper gender agreement in the translation:
Create a type associating the food order item to its size. For example, create an
structure containing two localizable string properties for
Add the necessary translations for the food items and the sizes to the Spanish localization file.
containing the English key phrase from the Spanish localization file to translate, along with the placeholder variable representing the phrase to inflect (
property an inflection concept of type
passing in the placeholder variable representing the phrase to inflect for that translation (
In the Spanish localization file, add
placeholders for the word you want to substitute for the size. Wrap the Spanish phrase for the size with the
attribute, with the index pointing to the first inflection concept instance in the
by passing the resource and options to a new

code: let order = Order(item: String(localized: "salad"), size: String(localized: "small"))
// Define the resource you want to apply grammatical agreement to.
let resource = LocalizedStringResource("Last time you ordered the \(order.size).")
// "Last time you ordered the %@." = "La última vez ordenaste ^[el %@](agreeWithConcept:1)."
// Set the inflection concept to a feminine localized phrase.
// Make a new string imposing grammatical agreement on the resource from the localized phrase.
let result = AttributedString(localized: resource, options: options)
// result == "La última vez ordenaste la pequeña."

abstract.text: A scope for accessing an inflection rule attribute.
A scope for accessing a morphology attribute.
A scope for accessing an inflection alternative attribute.
A scope for accessing an agreement concept attribute.
A scope for accessing a referent concept attribute.
A scope for accessing an agreement argument attribute.
An attribute that represents grammatical agreement with an argument in a localized string.
An attribute that represents grammatical agreement for objects that aren’t part of the inflected text.
An attribute that provides an alternative inflection phrase when the system can’t achieve grammatical agreement.
A type for using an inflection rule as an attribute.
A type for using a morphology as an attribute.
An attribute that specifies a grammatical agreement concept for substituting pronouns in localized text.
